3C: Data Preparation

Single Data Frame Functionality

Modules and Data

import polars as pl

hotels = pl.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tidyverse/datascience-box/refs/heads/main/course-materials/_slides/u2-d06-grammar-wrangle/data/hotels.csv",
                     null_values = ["NA"])

Data: Hotel bookings

  • Data from two hotels: one resort and one city hotel
  • Observations: Each row represents a hotel booking
hotels = pl.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tidyverse/datascience-box/refs/heads/main/course-materials/_slides/u2-d06-grammar-wrangle/data/hotels.csv",
                     null_values = ["NA"])

select a range of variables

(
  hotels
    .select(
      pl.nth(range(hotels.get_column_index("hotel"),
                   hotels.get_column_index("arrival_date_month")))
    )
)

"A" "A" "No Deposit" "Transient"
"A" "A" "No Deposit" "Transient"

Select helpers

  • starts_with(): Starts with a prefix
  • ends_with(): Ends with a suffix
  • contains(): Contains a literal string
  • num_range(): Matches a numerical range like x01, x02, x03
  • one_of(): Matches variable names in a character vector
  • everything(): Matches all variables
  • last_col(): Select last variable, possibly with an offset
  • matches(): Matches a regular expression (a sequence of symbols/characters expressing a string/pattern to be searched for within text)

See help for any of these functions for more info, e.g. ?everything.

    .select(["adults", "children", "babies"])

In Python, you can use the # for adding comments to your code. Any text following # will be printed as is, and won’t be run as R code. This is useful for leaving comments in your code and for temporarily disabling certain lines of code while debugging.

(
  hotels
  # slice the first five rows  # this line is a comment
  # .select("hotel")           # this one doesn't run
  .slice(0, 5)                 # Selects the first 5 rows
)

filter

filter to select a subset of rows

# bookings in City Hotels
(
  hotels
    .filter(pl.col("hotel") == "City Hotel")
)

filter for many conditions at once

(
  hotels
    .filter( 
      pl.col("adults") == 0,     
      pl.col("children") >= 1    
    )  
    .select(["adults", "babies", "children"])
)
shape: (223, 3)
adults babies children
i64 i64 i64
0 0 3
0 0 2
0 0 2
0 0 2
0 0 2
… … …
0 0 2
0 0 2
0 0 2
0 0 2
0 0 3

filter for more complex conditions

# bookings with no adults and some children or babies in the room
(
  hotels
    .filter( 
      pl.col("adults") == 0,     
      (pl.col("children") >= 1) | (pl.col("babies") >=1)    
    )  
    .select(["adults", "babies", "children"])
)
shape: (223, 3)
adults babies children
i64 i64 i64
0 0 3
0 0 2
0 0 2
0 0 2
0 0 2
… … …
0 0 2
0 0 2
0 0 2
0 0 2
0 0 3

Logical operators in Python


operator | definition || operator | definition ————|——————————||————–|—————- < | less than ||x | y | x OR y <= | less than or equal to ||is.na(x) | test if x is NA > | greater than ||!is.na(x) | test if x is not NA >= | greater than or equal to ||x %in% y | test if x is in y == | exactly equal to ||!(x %in% y) | test if x is not in y != | not equal to ||!x | not x x & y | x AND y || |

unique

unique to filter for unique rows

… and sort to order alphabetically

(
  hotels
    .unique("market_segment")
    .select("market_segment")
    .sort("market_segment")
)
shape: (8, 1)

with_columns

with_columns to add a new variable

(
  hotels
    .with_columns(
      little_ones = pl.col("children") + pl.col("babies")
    )
    .select("children", "babies", "little_ones")
    .sort("little_ones", descending = True)
)
shape: (119_390, 3)
children babies little_ones
i64 i64 i64

0 0 0

Little ones in resort and city hotels

# Resort Hotel
(
  hotels
    .with_columns(
      little_ones = pl.col("children") + pl.col("babies")
    )
    .filter(
      pl.col("little_ones") >= 1,
      pl.col("hotel") == "Resort Hotel"
    )
    .select("children", "babies", "little_ones")
)
shape: (3_929, 3)

      little_ones = pl.col("children") + pl.col("babies")
    )

      pl.col("hotel") == "City Hotel"
    )
    .select("children", "babies", "little_ones")
)

Summary Statistics

Summary Statistics

# mean average daily rate for all bookings
(
  hotels
    .select(pl.mean("adr"))
)
shape: (1, 1)
adr
f64
101.831122

agg and group_by

group_by for grouped operations

# mean average daily rate for all booking at city and resort hotels
(
  hotels
    .group_by("hotel")
)
<polars.dataframe.group_by.GroupBy at 0x7f01d4e1d160>

agg for summary stats

( hotels .group_by(“hotel”) .agg(mean_adr = pl.mean(“adr”), median_adr = pl.median(“adr”) ) )

(
  hotels
    .group_by("hotel")
    .agg(mean_adr = pl.mean("adr"))
)
shape: (2, 2)
hotel mean_adr
str f64
"City Hotel" 105.304465
"Resort Hotel" 94.95293

agg for multi summary stats

(
  hotels
    .group_by("hotel")
    .agg(mean_adr = pl.mean("adr"),
         median_adr = pl.median("adr")
    )
)
shape: (2, 3)
hotel mean_adr median_adr
str f64 f64
"Resort Hotel" 94.95293 75.0
"City Hotel" 105.304465 99.9

agg for correlation

(
  hotels
    .group_by("hotel")
    .agg(mean_adr = pl.mean("adr"),
         median_adr = pl.median("adr"),
         corr_child_babies = pl.corr("children", "babies")
    )
)
shape: (2, 4)
hotel mean_adr median_adr corr_child_babies
str f64 f64 f64
"City Hotel" 105.304465 99.9 0.023773
"Resort Hotel" 94.95293 75.0 0.020415

Calculating Frequencies

(
  hotels
    .select("market_segment")
    .group_by("market_segment")
    .agg(count = pl.len())
)
shape: (8, 2)

"Aviation" 237
"Corporate" 5295

order matters when you len

# hotel type first
(
  hotels
    .select("hotel", "market_segment")
    .group_by("hotel", "market_segment")
    .agg(count = pl.len())
)

What is happening in the following chunk?

(
  hotels
    .with_columns(
      little_ones = pl.col("children") + pl.col("babies")
    )
    .filter(
      pl.col("little_ones") >= 1,
      pl.col("hotel") == "City Hotel"
    )
    .select("children", "babies", "little_ones")
)
